p:
I used phenological and temperature and precipitation data from the USA-NPN repository for this study
14 . USA-NPN organizes and shares phenological data collected by scientists, citizen scientists, government organizations, non-government organizations, educators, and students that researchers can use to better understand and quantify the biological consequences of climate change. I downloaded all data for A. syriaca from the repository for the years 2011 through 2016. I only included “yes” status phenological measurements in our analysis, which indicate the presence of the phenophase, such as flowering. More importantly, I only included “yes” status measurements that were preceded by “no” measurements within a given year to reduce the bias of incomplete surveying that may occur with data collected by citizen scientists. The climate data, daily maximum temperature and precipitation values, for the location of each plant in the USA-NPN repository was provided by DAYMET ( https://daymet.ornl.gov), which is a resource provided by NASA that gives daily climate summaries at a 1 km x 1 km spatial resolution. Also, I downloaded monthly state level maximum temperature and precipitation data from the NOAA website
15 to compare contemporary (2011 through 2016) to historical (dating back to 1895) climate data.
